name: phoenicopterus-roseus
definition: The greater flamingo is the most widespread and largest species of the flamingo family.
description:
Greater flamingos are likely to be the only tall, pink bird in any given locale.

Greater flamingos have long, lean, curved necks and black-tipped bills with a distinctive downward bend.

Most of the plumage is pinkish-white, but the wing coverts are red and the primary and secondary flight feathers are black.

The bill is pink with a restricted black tip, and the legs are entirely pink.

Chicks are covered in gray fluffy down. Subadult flamingos are paler with dark legs.

Greater flamingos are capable flyers, and flamingos in captivity often require wing clipping to prevent escape.

Greater flamingos are found in a variety of saltwater habitats including salt or alkaline lakes, estuaries, shallow coastal lagoons and mudflats.

They rarely inhabits areas of freshwater other than using freshwater inlets for bathing and drinking.

Greater flamingo is an omnivore, filter-feeder.

It uses its feet to stir up the mud, then sucks water through its bill and filters out small shrimp, seeds, blue-green algae as well as larva, small insects, and mollusks and crustaceans.

The greater flamingo feeds with its head down, and its upper jaw is movable and not rigidly fixed to its skull.

Their bills are specially adapted to separate mud and silt from the food they eat.

The filtering of food items is assisted by hairy structures called lamellae, which line the mandibles, and the large, rough-surfaced tongue.

Greater flamingos are are monogamous, meaning pairs stay together for life.

They breed during April and May while gathered in groups on the extensive, warm, watery mudflats.

Greater flamingos build their nests in pairs. Nests are made out of hardened mud with a shallow depression in the top.

Like all species of flamingo, the female lays a single chalky-white egg. The mating pair take turns to incubate it.

The egg hatches after 27 to 31 days and the parents help the chick out of the egg by pulling pieces of the shell away.

Greater flamingos live and feed in groups called flocks or colonies.

They find safety in numbers, which helps to protect individual birds from predators while their heads are down in the mud.

The call is a goose-like honking.

Adult greater flamingos have few natural predators.

Eggs and chicks may be eaten by raptors, crows, gulls, and the marabou stork; an estimated half of the predation of greater flamingo eggs and chicks is from the yellow-legged gull.

featured.caption:
Greater flamingos are capable flyers.

They fly with long neck and legs extended, when deep pink-and-black wing pattern is strikingly visible.
